DOC.HEAD: Tutu Condemns Israeli Treatment of Palestinians
With-AM-World Christmas, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Archbishop Desmond Tutu of South Africa on Monday compared his country's suppression of blacks to Israel's treatment of Palestinians in the occupied lands, where Christmas celebrations were subdued because of the Arab uprising. The Nobel Peace Prize laureate came under increased criticism from Jews and also Christians sympathetic to Israel, who accused him of taking a one-sided approach to the Middle East conflict during his five-day trip. ``Members of our team have remarked on the similarities between the situation in the occupied territories and that in South Africa,'' Tutu told reporters. ``In the methods of resistance used by Palestinians, and in the ways the Israeli government deals with the resistance, we experienced an extraordinary sense of being at home,'' he said. In the West Bank city of Bethlehem, hundreds of Christian pilgrims marked Christmas with a visit to St. Catherine's basilica in Manger Square, the legendary site of Jesus' birth. Israeli soldiers removed barricades and metal detectors from Manger Square after Christmas Eve passed without incident. But the military presence was heavy, and at least 50 paratroopers and soldiers from the elite Givati brigade patrolled the square. ``I don't like it, but I guess it's for security,'' said Sara Paredes, 20, of Fort Leavenworth, Kan. as she stood outside the Church of the Nativity. Paredes said making a pilgrimage to Bethlehem was a ``dream'' for her, but added that she would like to return in the future when tensions and security are lessened and ``when I can find a better Christmas.'' Twenty Palestinians were wounded after troops opened fire on stone-throwing demonstrators in the Gaza Strip, Arab reports said. The army said it was investigating the reports. Tutu drew harsh criticism after he refused to meet with a delegation of Ethiopian Jews, saying their visit to the St. George Anglican Church in East Jerusalem was not on his schedule. ``He did not have time to sit with us, even for two or three minutes,'' Yitzhak Rahamim, a spokesman for the Ethiopian Immigrants Association told a reporter outside the church. ``I heard he had time to meet with Palestinians, but not with Jews, even with us from Africa.'' Tutu met Monday with a group of prominent Palestinian leaders to discuss the situation in the occupied territories, where Palestinians began their revolt against Israeli rule in December 1987. The Jerusalem-based International Christian Embassy, headed by Willem van der Hoeven, a Dutch Evangelist cleric, published a statement denouncing Tutu's repeated expressions of support for Palestinians. In the statement that was also sent to Israeli leaders, Van der Hoeven wrote: ``we specifically apologize for the remarks made by the visiting Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu...we bow our heads in shame.'' Tutu's endorsement of a Palestinian state has alienated many Israelis, and Israel's two chief rabbis refused to meet with the Anglican human rights leader. When asked to comment on criticisms of his visit, Tutu replied: ``The bible...speaks about Israel as being an agent of God for establishing justice and peace, and there is no way I am going to say the way Israel is treating Palestinians is just. And if they revile me for that, tough luck.''
